soln_description:
To prove when $n=1$, then since $\sum_{d \mid n} \mu(d)=\mu(1)=1$, the lemma holds.

Now suppose $n \geqslant 2$ is an integer. When $m$ is a positive integer and $m \mid n$, we use the notation $\sum_{m \mid d \mid n}$ to denote a sum over all divisors $d$ of $n$ that are divisible by $m$. In particular, when $m=1$, $\sum_{1 \mid d \mid n}$ is the same as $\sum_{d \mid n}$. Now let $p$ be a prime, then we have
$$\sum_{d \mid p} \mu(d)=1+\mu(p)=1-1=0$$

Now let $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{l}$ be $l$ distinct primes, we first prove
$$\sum_{d \mid p_{1} \cdots p_{l}} \mu(d)=0$$

When $l=1$, by (56) we know (57) holds. Now suppose $k \geqslant 2$ and (57) holds for $i=1, \cdots, k-1$, i.e.,
$$\sum_{d \mid p_{1} \cdots p_{k-1}} \mu(d)=0$$

Then by $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{k}$ being $k$ distinct primes and Lemma 13, we have
$$\begin{array}{l}
\sum_{d \mid p_{1} \cdots p_{k}} \mu(d)=\sum_{d \mid p_{1} \cdots p_{k-1}} \mu(d)+\sum_{p_{k} \mid d \mid p_{1} \cdots p_{k}} \mu(d) \\
\quad=\left(1+\mu\left(p_{k}\right)\right) \sum_{d \mid p_{1} \cdots p_{k-1}} \mu(d)=0
\end{array}$$

Thus, when $l=k$, (57) also holds, and by mathematical induction, (57) holds.

Let $n=p_{1}^{a_{1}} \cdots p_{l}^{a_{l}}$, where $p_{1}, \cdots, p_{l}$ are $l$ distinct primes, and $a_{1}, \cdots, a_{l}$ are $l$ positive integers. Since $\mu(d)=0$ when $d$ is divisible by the square of a prime, by (57) we have
$$\sum_{d \mid n} \mu(d)=\sum_{d \mid p_{1} \cdots p_{l}} \mu(d)=0$$

Thus, the lemma is proved.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Lemma 14 We have
$$\sum_{d \mid n} \mu(d)=\left\{\begin{array}{l}
1, \text { when } n=1 \text { ; } \\
0, \text { when } n>1 \text { . }
\end{array}\right.$$ -/
theorem number_theory_6989 (n : ‚Ñï) :
    ‚àë d in n.divisors, ArithmeticFunction.moebius d = if n = 1 then 1 else 0 := by

soln_description:
Solution: $1-\ln (e-1)$
Since $\ln \left(1+e^{2^{k}}\right)$ is just larger than $2^{k}$, its fractional part is $\ln \left(1+e^{2^{k}}\right)-\ln e^{2^{k}}=$ $\ln \left(1+e^{-2^{k}}\right)$. But now notice that
$$
\prod_{k=0}^{n}\left(1+x^{2^{k}}\right)=1+x+x^{2}+\cdots+x^{2^{n+1}-1} .
$$
(This is easily proven by induction or by noting that every nonnegative integer less than $2^{n+1}$ has a unique $(n+1)$-bit binary expansion.) If $|x|<1$, this product converges to $\frac{1}{1-x}$ as $n$ goes to infinity. Therefore,
$$
\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \ln \left(1+e^{-2^{k}}\right)=\ln \prod_{k=0}^{\infty}\left(1+\left(e^{-1}\right)^{2^{k}}\right)=\ln \frac{1}{1-e^{-1}}=\ln \frac{e}{e-1}=1-\ln (e-1) .
$$

$$
where $\{x\}=x-\lfloor x\rfloor$ denotes the fractional part of $x$.

$$
where $\{x\}=x-\lfloor x\rfloor$ denotes the fractional part of $x$. -/

soln_description:
## Solution

$$
\int_{6}^{10} \sqrt{\frac{4-x}{x-12}} d x=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t=\sqrt{\frac{4-x}{x-12}} \Rightarrow t^{2}=\frac{4-x}{x-12}=-\frac{x-12+8}{x-12}=-1-\frac{8}{x-12} \Rightarrow \\
& \Rightarrow 12-x=\frac{8}{t^{2}+1} \Rightarrow x=-\frac{8}{t^{2}+1}+12 \\
& d x=\frac{8}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot 2 t \cdot d t=\frac{16 t}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot d t \\
& x=6 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt{\frac{4-6}{6-12}}=\sqrt{\frac{-2}{-6}}=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \\
& x=10 \Rightarrow t=\sqrt{\frac{4-10}{10-12}}=\sqrt{\frac{-6}{-2}}=\sqrt{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
=\int_{\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}}^{\sqrt{3}} t \cdot \frac{16 t}{\left(t^{2}+1\right)^{2}} \cdot d t=
$$

Substitution:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& t=\tan z, d t=\frac{d z}{\cos ^{2} z} \\
& t=\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}} \Rightarrow z=\arctan \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}=\frac{\pi}{6} \\
& t=\sqrt{3} \Rightarrow z=\arctan \sqrt{3}=\frac{\pi}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

We get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& =16 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan^{2} z}{\left(\tan^{2} z+1\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{d z}{\cos ^{2} z}=16 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \frac{\tan^{2} z}{\left(\frac{1}{\cos ^{2} z}\right)^{2}} \cdot \frac{d z}{\cos ^{2} z}=16 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \tan^{2} z \cdot \cos ^{2} z \cdot d z= \\
& =16 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3} \sin ^{2} z \cdot d z=8 \cdot \int_{\pi / 6}^{\pi / 3}(1-\cos 2 z) d z=\left.8 \cdot\left(z-\frac{\sin 2 z}{2}\right)\right|_{\pi / 6} ^{\pi / 3}= \\
& =8 \cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{3}-\frac{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{3}}{2}\right)-8 \cdot\left(\frac{\pi}{6}-\frac{\sin \frac{2 \pi}{6}}{2}\right)=\frac{8 \pi}{3}-4 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{4 \pi}{3}+4 \cdot \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=\frac{4 \pi}{3}
\end{aligned}
$$

soln_description:
The cyclist must follow the field at the speed $v_{F}$. Then, for the distances covered, since he is short of $3 \mathrm{~min}=\frac{1}{20}$ time $(t=$ driving time for the $20 \mathrm{~km})$:

Cyclist: $v_{F} \cdot\left(t-\frac{1}{20}\right)=20$, from which it follows

Field: $40 \cdot t=20 ; t=0.5 \mathrm{~h} ; V_{F}=44.4 \frac{\mathrm{km}}{\mathrm{h}}$
informal_statement:
## 146. Math Puzzle $7 / 77$

During a section of a cycling race, the peloton is rolling at $v=40 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. A rider loses three minutes due to a flat tire.

At what speed must he chase the peloton to catch up after $20 \mathrm{~km}$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- ## 146. Math Puzzle $7 / 77$

During a section of a cycling race, the peloton is rolling at $v=40 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}$. A rider loses three minutes due to a flat tire.

At what speed must he chase the peloton to catch up after $20 \mathrm{~km}$? -/
theorem algebra_141569 (v : ‚Ñù) (h : v > 0) (h' : 20 / v = 20 / 40 - 3 / 60) :
    v = 44.4 := by
